story.storybody:
The business of private developers flourished in Millennium City over the years as groundwater was easily available. But now, they are being accused for pushing city's groundwater table to the dark zone by constructing the multi-storey buildings in the city. The Haryana Urban Development Authority (HUDA) is unable to meet the water demands of these high-rise apartments.

Hence, they have licenced submersible pumps which have been extracting large amount of water on daily basis. "People like me, who reside in Huda sectors or residential societies, have been severely hit by this water crisis. We do not have the permission to install submersible pumps and Huda too is unable to provide water on a regular basis," said Satpal Thakran, RWA president of Mayfield garden at Sector 51.

WATER CRISIS

He added that Huda installed pipelines in all 13 blocks in Mayfield garden but the taps remains dry throughout the summer season. Another resident, Jyoti Malhotra, said that every block has a separate under-ground water tank having capacity of 1.12 lakh litre but each family is permitted to draw just 80 litre per day. Jyoti claimed that each block's requirement is over 3 lakh litre per day. "Huda has been unable to fill these tanks seven out of 10 times. We are completely dependent on water tankers that charge Rs 1,800 to 2,500 per unit," she said. The geographical location of Gurugram is such that supply from two main water treatment plant -Basai and Chandu Budhera - do not reach the upscale localities such as DLF city phase 1, 2, 3, 4,5 or residential societies situated in sector 56 areas. The Basai water treatment plant has a maximum capacity of 60 million gallons (MG) per day while Chandu Budhera has 22 million gallons.

Sunil Goswami, a resident of DLF phase 1, said, "Forty per cent residents of his S block locality suffer due to erratic water supply. "Private localities do not figure in Huda's priority list and more over there is no coordination between power distribution body, Dakshin Haryana Bijli Vitran Nigam Ltd., and Huda. There are power-cuts, especially in the morning and evening, when we need to operate the water pumps," Goswami said. Even Huda administrator Yash Pal admits about water crisis being genuine in DLF city.
